pageContext.claim: “Then you see 99.99 percent of the things get approved, it was supposed to be just the opposite.”
pageContext.analysis: Between 1979 and 2012—the first thirty-three years of the FISC’s existence—federal agencies submitted 33,900 ex parte requests to the court. The judges denied eleven and granted the rest: a 99.97% rate of approval. The denial rate increased slightly in Trump's first year in office. But it is not supposed to be the opposite. An article in the Stanford Law Review argued that because the executive branch has long-running knowledge of how the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court treats applications, there is little reason to expect agencies to submit losing requests.
